name: Sakura-iro
meaning: The pale pink color of cherry blossoms. A symbol of spring and fleeting beauty in Japanese culture.

name: Momo-iro
meaning: Peach color. Associated with the Girls' Festival (Hinamatsuri) and longevity.

name: Koubai-iro
meaning: Red plum blossom color. A slightly purplish red, signaling early spring.

name: Shojouhi
meaning: A vivid scarlet derived from the mythical Shojo creature's blood/hair. Used in Kabuki costumes.

name: Shu-iro
meaning: Cinnabar red. Commonly seen on Torii gates at Shinto shrines, believed to ward off evil.

name: Yamabuki-iro
meaning: Bright golden yellow of the Japanese kerria flower. Historically associated with gold coins.

name: Oudo-iro
meaning: Ocher or yellow earth color. A traditional pigment used in art and dyeing.

name: Moegi-iro
meaning: Fresh onion chive color. Represents the yellowish-green of young sprouts in early spring.

name: Uguisu-iro
meaning: Color of the Japanese Bush Warbler's wings. A muted olive green synonymous with refined taste.

name: Tokiwa-iro
meaning: Evergreen color. Represents eternity and constancy, like evergreen pine trees.

name: Ruri-iro
meaning: Lapis Lazuli color. A deep, vivid blue highly generated in Buddhism as one of the Seven Treasures.

name: Ai-iro
meaning: Indigo blue. The most common dye in Edo Japan, often called 'Japan Blue'.

name: Katsu-iro
meaning: Winning color. A very dark indigo favored by samurai for its auspicious name (homophone for 'victory').

name: Murasaki
meaning: Purple. Historically restricted to the highest ranks of nobility and royalty in Japan.

name: Fuji-iro
meaning: Wisteria color. A pale purple beloved in the Heian period, often associated with elegant women.

name: Botan-iro
meaning: Peony color. A vivid purplish red symbolizing wealth and feminine beauty.

name: Nezumi-iro
meaning: Mouse grey. Popular in the Edo period as a discreet, chic color for commoners forbidden from wearing brights.

name: Rikyu-cha
meaning: Rikyu's Tea color. A greenish brown named after the famous tea master Sen no Rikyu.

name: Kuro-tsurubami
meaning: Black acorn. A deep black dye used for high-ranking officials' robes.

name: Gofun
meaning: Chalk white. A white pigment made from crushed seashells, used in Nihonga painting and doll making.
